enduring freedom 's shift in focus belies horn of africa 's security threat -pipe- world -pipe- deutsche welle -pipe- 05.07.2010 main content main navigation extra content head navigation search choose form 30 languages about us press business & sales dw-akademie dw-store contact help partner site map archive search keywords search extended search your link to germany choose from 30 languages choose from 30 languages choose from 30 languages english german chinese spanish portuguese for brazil arabic russian persian albanian amharic bengali bosnian b / h / s bulgarian croatian dari french greek hausa hindi indonesian kiswahili macedonian pashto polish portuguese romanian serbian turkish ukrainian urdu choose from 30 languages 12.10.2010 home news germany europe world from tierra del fuego to tijuana asia business science & technology environment & development culture & lifestyle sports germany info visit germany facts about germany study in germany german courses learning german deutsch unterrichten german xxl dw-radio what 's on ?
programs reception audio on demand learning by ear dw-tv what 's on ?
program guide programs video on demand reception about dw-tv interactive reader response newsletters web tools and services podcasting mobile about dw-world.de terrorism -pipe- 05.07.2010 enduring freedom 's shift in focus belies horn of africa 's security threat großansicht des bildes mit der bildunterschrift : german marines will now search for pirates not terrorists germany 's recent decision to pull out of operation enduring freedom was based on an assessment that labels the terror threat in the horn of africa as limited .
defense analysts suggest the region is still a major concern . if the german defense ministry is to be believed , the terrorist threat in the sea off the horn of africa has been reduced so significantly that it sees no further reason to deploy its force of 90 marines and a navy reconnaissance plane as part of the us-led operation enduring freedom .
due to an assessment that claims that the threat is now ' limited , ' germany has ended its involvement six months earlier than its mandate stipulated .
germany has been involved in the operation enduring freedom as part of the mission aimed at stopping islamic terrorists smuggling arms to groups in africa from the arabian peninsula for over eight years .
the german navy joined the task force in february 2002 , some five months after the united states established the operation after the 9/11 attacks on new york and washington .
with the last german troops completing their tours of duty in the gulf of aden and the indian ocean last week , germany 's naval focus now shifts to the mediterranean .
one german navy frigate will remain off the coast of africa as part of operation atalanta , a european union mission to protect aid shipments into somalia from pirate attack .
however , with increased al qaeda activity being reported across the gulf of aden in yemen , affiliated islamist groups continuing to battle for control of somalia and reports that osama bin laden 's terror network is extending its influence into kenya , the german decision has caused some surprise among security analysts .
somalia at the heart of region 's spreading extremism bildunterschrift : großansicht des bildes mit der bildunterschrift : al shabab is fighting to install an islamic caliphate in somalia " the terrorist threat emanating from the horn of africa is limited at the moment , " jeremy binnie , a terrorism expert at jane 's defence group , told deutsche welle .
" however , there is a lot of concern that somalia might turn into something akin to taliban-controlled afghanistan in the 1990s .
the pro-al qaeda group there , the shabab , controls much of the south of the country and is currently threatening to overrun mogadishu .
the only thing stopping them is a small force of african peacekeepers .
so there are worries that southern somalia could become a safe haven for jihadists from other countries and a base for training . "
" there are already indications that the shabab is being supported by a small number of foreign jihadists and has recruited possibly hundreds of young men from europe and north america , most of them somalis , " binnie added .
" there have also been a few reports of yemen-based al qaeda operatives turning up in somalia .
the worry is that these guys could be used to carry out international terrorist attacks . "
" at the same time , there are worries about the geographical proximity between somalia and yemen , meaning it is possible that the shabab will link up with bin laden 's yemeni branch , al qaeda on the arabian peninsula . "
yemen supply lines still bringing arms , personnel to africa last year 's failed bombing of a detroit-bound airliner by an al qaeda suspect with links to yemen highlighted the country 's growing reputation as the new hub for terrorism in the region .
yemen is a blueprint nation for radical islamists ; it has a weak government , it is deeply divided by a tribalistic and violent civil war which is pushing the country toward the status of a failed state and has a culture in which most men carry weapons , therefore making identifying terrorists extremely difficult .
the land of osama bin laden 's ancestors has also become a melting pot of refugees from the conflict in somalia and returning jihadists from the wars in afghanistan and iraq .
with africa in its sights , it is thought that al qaeda sees yemen as an ideal staging point for fanning the flames of extremism across the gulf of aden in somalia and beyond .
bildunterschrift : großansicht des bildes mit der bildunterschrift : al qaeda has targeted kenya since the us embassy attack despite having a less direct shipping connection to yemen than somalia , sharing a border with the failed state puts kenya at risk of infiltration by islamist terror groups .
instead of having to navigate through the international forces in indian ocean to reach the kenyan coastline , arab-based terrorists can smuggle weapons and personnel overland to kenya via somalia .
it has been reported for as long as germany was part of operation enduring freedom that al qaeda was seeking a foothold in kenya and that al qaeda operatives had infiltrated the country 's islamic communities on its indian ocean coast .
poor relations between kenya 's coastal muslims and the country 's inefficient security forces have provided al qaeda with a new base from which it can extend its growing network throughout eastern africa .
inland in kenya , border camps filled with refugees from somalia are reported to be just as fertile a breeding ground for young extremists .
meanwhile , kenya has its own home grown terror problem .
the kenyan saleh ali saleh nabhan was alleged to have been the leader of al qaeda in somalia and the mastermind behind the bombing of the paradise hotel in mombasa and the attempted downing of an israeli passenger jet in november 2002 .
he was also suspected of involvement in the 1998 us embassy bombings in nairobi and dar es salaam in tanzania .
he was killed by us special forces near mogadishu in september 2009 .
changing face of mission shifts threat focus david hartwell , an expert and risk analyst for the middle east and north africa , believes that the changing nature of operation enduring freedom has shifted the focus away from its original mission meaning that the horn of africa and land-based threats are now longer in its remit . bildunterschrift : großansicht des bildes mit der bildunterschrift : german troops will leave but the threat will remain " the germans have made a fair assessment on enduring freedom but it 's one based on the level of threat within the operation 's initial mission which was to capture fleeing extremists and taliban from afghanistan and stop them getting to places like yemen , saudi arabia and oman , " hartwell told deutsche welle . " in its original form , it has n't recorded that many successes as there have been few significant arrests of wanted figures on the seas .
as such , enduring freedom has mutated into the anti-piracy mission which is having more success in containing the pirates .
but it has been agreed that there is less of a need for naval forces to be searching for fleeing extremists now , especially in the gulf of aden and indian ocean . " " the region itself is still unstable with civil wars and extremism in both somalia and yemen but those involved in enduring freedom are wary of getting involved in the internal politics in these countries so we 'll see more countries following germany 's decision and refocusing on the piracy mission , " he added . author : nick amies editor : rob mudge send us an e-mail » -pipe- send » -pipe- print » more on the topic share this article what is social bookmarking ?
dw-world.de us support for somali government raises questions over military aid concern that us military aid and support to the government of somalia may have breached a number of international laws turns the spotlight on washington 's involvement in a country it was supposed to have left years ago .
-lrb- 26.06.2010 -rrb- germany to streamline its international military missions german defense minister karl-theodor zu guttenberg is on a two-day trip to visit troops on the horn of africa and cyprus .
he has stressed that , although smaller , their missions are still important .
-lrb- 23.06.2010 -rrb- us determination may not be enough to combat al qaeda in yemen with the us sinking $ 150 million -lrb- 110 million euros -rrb- into the fight against al qaeda , it 's taking a tough stance on the terror group in yemen .
but is president saleh actually interested in removing them from yemen ? -lrb- 22.03.2010 -rrb- feedback is germany right to withdraw from operations off the horn of africa ?
send us an e-mail .
please include your name and country in your reply .

the kenyan saleh ali saleh nabhan was alleged to have been the leader of al qaeda in somalia and the mastermind behind the bombing of the paradise hotel in mombasa and the attempted downing of an israeli passenger jet in november 2002 .
he was also suspected of involvement in the 1998 us embassy bombings in nairobi and dar es salaam in tanzania .
he was killed by us special forces near mogadishu in september 2009 .
changing face of mission shifts threat focus david hartwell , an expert and risk analyst for the middle east and north africa , believes that the changing nature of operation enduring freedom has shifted the focus away from its original mission meaning that the horn of africa and land-based threats are now longer in its remit . bildunterschrift : großansicht des bildes mit der bildunterschrift : german troops will leave but the threat will remain " the germans have made a fair assessment on enduring freedom but it 's one based on the level of threat within the operation 's initial mission which was to capture fleeing extremists and taliban from afghanistan and stop them getting to places like yemen , saudi arabia and oman , " hartwell told deutsche welle . " in its original form , it has n't recorded that many successes as there have been few significant arrests of wanted figures on the seas .
as such , enduring freedom has mutated into the anti-piracy mission which is having more success in containing the pirates .
but it has been agreed that there is less of a need for naval forces to be searching for fleeing extremists now , especially in the gulf of aden and indian ocean . " " the region itself is still unstable with civil wars and extremism in both somalia and yemen but those involved in enduring freedom are wary of getting involved in the internal politics in these countries so we 'll see more countries following germany 's decision and refocusing on the piracy mission , " he added . author : nick amies editor : rob mudge send us an e-mail » -pipe- send » -pipe- print » more on the topic share this article what is social bookmarking ?
dw-world.de us support for somali government raises questions over military aid concern that us military aid and support to the government of somalia may have breached a number of international laws turns the spotlight on washington 's involvement in a country it was supposed to have left years ago .
-lrb- 26.06.2010 -rrb- germany to streamline its international military missions german defense minister karl-theodor zu guttenberg is on a two-day trip to visit troops on the horn of africa and cyprus .
he has stressed that , although smaller , their missions are still important .
-lrb- 23.06.2010 -rrb- us determination may not be enough to combat al qaeda in yemen with the us sinking $ 150 million -lrb- 110 million euros -rrb- into the fight against al qaeda , it 's taking a tough stance on the terror group in yemen .
but is president saleh actually interested in removing them from yemen ? -lrb- 22.03.2010 -rrb- feedback is germany right to withdraw from operations off the horn of africa ?
send us an e-mail .
please include your name and country in your reply .

enduring freedom 's shift in focus belies horn of africa 's security threat -pipe- world -pipe- deutsche welle -pipe- 05.07.2010 main content main navigation extra content head navigation search choose form 30 languages about us press business & sales dw-akademie dw-store contact help partner site map archive search keywords search extended search your link to germany choose from 30 languages choose from 30 languages choose from 30 languages english german chinese spanish portuguese for brazil arabic russian persian albanian amharic bengali bosnian b / h / s bulgarian croatian dari french greek hausa hindi indonesian kiswahili macedonian pashto polish portuguese for africa romanian serbian turkish ukrainian urdu choose from 30 languages 31.03.2011 home news germany europe world asia business science & technology environment & development culture & lifestyle sports germany info visit germany facts about germany study in germany german courses learning german deutsch unterrichten german xxl dw-radio what 's on ?
reception audio on demand learning by ear dw-tv what 's on ?
program guide programs video on demand reception about dw-tv interactive reader response newsletters web tools and services podcasting mobile about dw-world.de terrorism -pipe- 05.07.2010 enduring freedom 's shift in focus belies horn of africa 's security threat großansicht des bildes mit der bildunterschrift : german marines will now search for pirates not terrorists germany 's recent decision to pull out of operation enduring freedom was based on an assessment that labels the terror threat in the horn of africa as limited .
defense analysts suggest the region is still a major concern . if the german defense ministry is to be believed , the terrorist threat in the sea off the horn of africa has been reduced so significantly that it sees no further reason to deploy its force of 90 marines and a navy reconnaissance plane as part of the us-led operation enduring freedom .
due to an assessment that claims that the threat is now ' limited , ' germany has ended its involvement six months earlier than its mandate stipulated .
germany has been involved in the operation enduring freedom as part of the mission aimed at stopping islamic terrorists smuggling arms to groups in africa from the arabian peninsula for over eight years .
the german navy joined the task force in february 2002 , some five months after the united states established the operation after the 9/11 attacks on new york and washington .
with the last german troops completing their tours of duty in the gulf of aden and the indian ocean last week , germany 's naval focus now shifts to the mediterranean .
one german navy frigate will remain off the coast of africa as part of operation atalanta , a european union mission to protect aid shipments into somalia from pirate attack .
however , with increased al qaeda activity being reported across the gulf of aden in yemen , affiliated islamist groups continuing to battle for control of somalia and reports that osama bin laden 's terror network is extending its influence into kenya , the german decision has caused some surprise among security analysts .
somalia at the heart of region 's spreading extremism bildunterschrift : großansicht des bildes mit der bildunterschrift : al shabab is fighting to install an islamic caliphate in somalia " the terrorist threat emanating from the horn of africa is limited at the moment , " jeremy binnie , a terrorism expert at jane 's defence group , told deutsche welle .
" however , there is a lot of concern that somalia might turn into something akin to taliban-controlled afghanistan in the 1990s .
the pro-al qaeda group there , the shabab , controls much of the south of the country and is currently threatening to overrun mogadishu .
the only thing stopping them is a small force of african peacekeepers .
so there are worries that southern somalia could become a safe haven for jihadists from other countries and a base for training . "
" there are already indications that the shabab is being supported by a small number of foreign jihadists and has recruited possibly hundreds of young men from europe and north america , most of them somalis , " binnie added .
" there have also been a few reports of yemen-based al qaeda operatives turning up in somalia .
the worry is that these guys could be used to carry out international terrorist attacks . "
" at the same time , there are worries about the geographical proximity between somalia and yemen , meaning it is possible that the shabab will link up with bin laden 's yemeni branch , al qaeda on the arabian peninsula . "
yemen supply lines still bringing arms , personnel to africa last year 's failed bombing of a detroit-bound airliner by an al qaeda suspect with links to yemen highlighted the country 's growing reputation as the new hub for terrorism in the region .
yemen is a blueprint nation for radical islamists ; it has a weak government , it is deeply divided by a tribalistic and violent civil war which is pushing the country toward the status of a failed state and has a culture in which most men carry weapons , therefore making identifying terrorists extremely difficult .
the land of osama bin laden 's ancestors has also become a melting pot of refugees from the conflict in somalia and returning jihadists from the wars in afghanistan and iraq .
with africa in its sights , it is thought that al qaeda sees yemen as an ideal staging point for fanning the flames of extremism across the gulf of aden in somalia and beyond .
bildunterschrift : großansicht des bildes mit der bildunterschrift : al qaeda has targeted kenya since the us embassy attack despite having a less direct shipping connection to yemen than somalia , sharing a border with the failed state puts kenya at risk of infiltration by islamist terror groups .
instead of having to navigate through the international forces in indian ocean to reach the kenyan coastline , arab-based terrorists can smuggle weapons and personnel overland to kenya via somalia .
it has been reported for as long as germany was part of operation enduring freedom that al qaeda was seeking a foothold in kenya and that al qaeda operatives had infiltrated the country 's islamic communities on its indian ocean coast .
poor relations between kenya 's coastal muslims and the country 's inefficient security forces have provided al qaeda with a new base from which it can extend its growing network throughout eastern africa .
inland in kenya , border camps filled with refugees from somalia are reported to be just as fertile a breeding ground for young extremists .
meanwhile , kenya has its own home grown terror problem .
the kenyan saleh ali saleh nabhan was alleged to have been the leader of al qaeda in somalia and the mastermind behind the bombing of the paradise hotel in mombasa and the attempted downing of an israeli passenger jet in november 2002 .
he was also suspected of involvement in the 1998 us embassy bombings in nairobi and dar es salaam in tanzania .
he was killed by us special forces near mogadishu in september 2009 .
changing face of mission shifts threat focus david hartwell , an expert and risk analyst for the middle east and north africa , believes that the changing nature of operation enduring freedom has shifted the focus away from its original mission meaning that the horn of africa and land-based threats are now longer in its remit . bildunterschrift : großansicht des bildes mit der bildunterschrift : german troops will leave but the threat will remain " the germans have made a fair assessment on enduring freedom but it 's one based on the level of threat within the operation 's initial mission which was to capture fleeing extremists and taliban from afghanistan and stop them getting to places like yemen , saudi arabia and oman , " hartwell told deutsche welle . " in its original form , it has n't recorded that many successes as there have been few significant arrests of wanted figures on the seas .
as such , enduring freedom has mutated into the anti-piracy mission which is having more success in containing the pirates .
but it has been agreed that there is less of a need for naval forces to be searching for fleeing extremists now , especially in the gulf of aden and indian ocean . " " the region itself is still unstable with civil wars and extremism in both somalia and yemen but those involved in enduring freedom are wary of getting involved in the internal politics in these countries so we 'll see more countries following germany 's decision and refocusing on the piracy mission , " he added . author : nick amies editor : rob mudge send us an e-mail » -pipe- send » -pipe- print » more on the topic share this article what is social bookmarking ?

he has stressed that , although smaller , their missions are still important .
-lrb- 23.06.2010 -rrb- us determination may not be enough to combat al qaeda in yemen with the us sinking $ 150 million -lrb- 110 million euros -rrb- into the fight against al qaeda , it 's taking a tough stance on the terror group in yemen .
but is president saleh actually interested in removing them from yemen ? -lrb- 22.03.2010 -rrb- feedback is germany right to withdraw from operations off the horn of africa ?

bundles of booty where do dictators stash their cash ?
asset trackers use ' ladders ' to follow the money .

international conference media representatives around the world gather in bonn to discuss human rights .

bbc - suffolk sports awards 2010 seek nominations british broadcasting corporation home accessibility links skip to content skip to local navigation skip to bbc.co.uk navigation skip to bbc.co.uk search help accessibility help suffolk bbc radio suffolk listen live to bbc radio suffolk on iplayer listen again to bbc radio suffolk on iplayer bbc local suffolk things to do people & places nature & outdoors history religion & ethics arts & culture bbc introducing tv & radio local bbc sites news sport weather travel neighbouring sites cambridgeshire essex norfolk related bbc sites england page last updated at 05:21 gmt , monday , 5 july 2010 06:21 uk e-mail this to a friend printable version suffolk sports awards 2010 seek nominations by andrew woodger bbc suffolk chris walker-hebborn is hoping to make the 2012 gb swimming squad nominations are needed for the 14 categories in the suffolk sports awards 2010 .
bbc suffolk is sponsoring the unsung hero award which recognises volunteers who 've made outstanding contributions to their sport .
nominations close on 3 september with the awards ceremony taking place at trinity park on 17 october .
other categories include sports personality , coach , team and contribution to disability sport .
for the nomination form and full details visit the suffolk sports awards 2010 website .
chloe mcmorran , sports development officer with suffolk sport : " we 're continuing to reward and celebrate individual excellence , team achievement as well as recognising those people who work tirelessly behind the scenes .
" last year the focus was on the sports aid scholars and it gave them an opportunity to raise their profile and , again , we 're going to be focusing on the potential athletes for london 2012 as well as the current ones .
" the suffolk sports awards are seen as a key event in the journey to 2012 .
" everyone out there must know of a sporting hero who 's doing well at a local football or cricket club or behind the scenes at a tennis club .
" we have around 350 people in attendance at the sports awards and we 're all there for one purpose and that 's to celebrate sport . "
potential 2012 athletes at the 2009 awards ceremony were bury st edmunds swimmer chris walker-hebburn , recurve archer tom barber and javelin thrower matti mortimore .
in terms of funding , the suffolk awards help in a small way , with individual winners getting around £ 50 and teams getting £ 100 .
karen smith picks up her 2009 award from bbc suffolk 's bryan knights martial arts boost the winner of the 2009 unsung hero award was dr karen smith who , when she 's not testing vaccines at university college london , runs a martial arts school in sudbury .
karen is a ' kyo sa nim ' -lrb- 2nd degree black belt -rrb- in the korean sport of kuk sool won and she teaches self-defence , including work with vulnerable women and disadvantaged youngsters .
" i was absolutely shocked - i just thought it was wonderful to be invited along to the event .
" it really gave me an opportunity to publicise the school in a positive way .
if you 're a parent of a child , it gives you the confidence in the school to walk through the door in a way that , perhaps , you would n't have had otherwise .
" i discovered it at a demonstration at cornhill walk in bury st edmunds .
initially , my sons wanted to join and i was the ' mummy taxi service ' .
" one day , i gave in and took the shoes off and had a bash .
i 've been enjoying it ever since .
" i can only run this school through the support and good grace of my assistant instructors who give all their time freely as well .
" without them , it just would n't be possible .
i really see my award as a testament to them and to the students who come and make it a really nice atmosphere . "
the sudbury club now has 80 members and recently they 've added a third night of classes , which are held at afc sudbury 's community pavilion .
chloe mcmorran said it could help blow away the world cup blues resulting from england 's poor showing .
" i think it 's going to take a lot , " she said .
" but the suffolk sports awards is a fantastic event and hopefully a lot of the winners will go on further to regional awards and last year we had nick drane who actually went to the uk coaching awards and that was a fantastic achievement . "
the full list of categories is : sports personality of the year young sports personality of the year unsung hero lifetime achievement triumph over adversity coach of the year contribution to disability sport young community volunteer of the year club of the year senior team of the year junior team of the year primary school of the year secondary school of the year innovative project for the nomination form and full details visit the suffolk sports awards 2010 website .
bookmark with : delicious digg reddit facebook stumbleupon what are these ?

while you will be able to view the content of this page in your current browser , you will not be able to get the full visual experience .
please consider upgrading your browser software or enabling style sheets -lrb- css -rrb- if you are able to do so .

bbc - suffolk - suffolk sports awards 2010 launch / people & places bbc local -pipe- suffolk -pipe- things to do -pipe- people & places -pipe- tv & radio -pipe- 05:21 gmt , monday , 5 july 2010 06:21 uk suffolk sports awards 2010 launch by andrew woodger bbc suffolk nominations are needed for the 14 categories in the suffolk sports awards 2010 .
bbc suffolk is sponsoring the unsung hero award which recognises volunteers who 've made outstanding contributions to their sport .
nominations close on 3 september with the awards ceremony taking place at trinity park on 17 october .

" last year the focus was on the sports aid scholars and it gave them an opportunity to raise their profile and , again , we 're going to be focusing on the potential athletes for london 2012 as well as the current ones .
" the suffolk sports awards are seen as a key event in the journey to 2012 .
" everyone out there must know of a sporting hero who 's doing well at a local football or cricket club or behind the scenes at a tennis club .
" we have around 350 people in attendance at the sports awards and we 're all there for one purpose and that 's to celebrate sport . "
potential 2012 athletes at the 2009 awards ceremony were bury st edmunds swimmer chris walker-hebburn , recurve archer tom barber and javelin thrower matti mortimore .
in terms of funding , the suffolk awards help in a small way , with individual winners getting around £ 50 and teams getting £ 100 .
martial arts boost the winner of the 2009 unsung hero award was dr karen smith who , when she 's not testing vaccines at university college london , runs a martial arts school in sudbury .
karen is a ' kyo sa nim ' -lrb- 2nd degree black belt -rrb- in the korean sport of kuk sool won and she teaches self-defence , including work with vulnerable women and disadvantaged youngsters .
" i was absolutely shocked - i just thought it was wonderful to be invited along to the event .
" it really gave me an opportunity to publicise the school in a positive way .
if you 're a parent of a child , it gives you the confidence in the school to walk through the door in a way that , perhaps , you would n't have had otherwise .
" i discovered it at a demonstration at cornhill walk in bury st edmunds .
initially , my sons wanted to join and i was the ' mummy taxi service ' .
" one day , i gave in and took the shoes off and had a bash .
i 've been enjoying it ever since .
" i can only run this school through the support and good grace of my assistant instructors who give all their time freely as well .
" without them , it just would n't be possible .
i really see my award as a testament to them and to the students who come and make it a really nice atmosphere . "
the sudbury club now has 80 members and recently they 've added a third night of classes , which are held at afc sudbury 's community pavilion .
chloe mcmorran said it could help blow away the world cup blues resulting from england 's poor showing .
" i think it 's going to take a lot , " she said .
" but the suffolk sports awards is a fantastic event and hopefully a lot of the winners will go on further to regional awards and last year we had nick drane who actually went to the uk coaching awards and that was a fantastic achievement . "
the full list of categories is : sports personality of the year young sports personality of the year unsung hero lifetime achievement triumph over adversity coach of the year contribution to disability sport young community volunteer of the year club of the year senior team of the year junior team of the year primary school of the year secondary school of the year innovative project for the nomination form and full details visit the suffolk sports awards 2010 website .

bbc - llangollen international music eisteddfod 2010 line-up british broadcasting corporation home accessibility links skip to content skip to local navigation skip to bbc.co.uk navigation skip to bbc.co.uk search help accessibility help north east wales bbc radio wales listen live to bbc radio wales on iplayer listen again to bbc radio wales on iplayer bbc local north east wales things to do people & places nature & outdoors history religion & ethics arts & culture music tv & radio local bbc sites news sport weather travel neighbouring sites liverpool mid wales north west wales shropshire related bbc sites wales cymru gogledd ddwyrain page last updated at 07:02 gmt , monday , 5 july 2010 08:02 uk e-mail this to a friend printable version llangollen international music eisteddfod 2010 line-up katherine jenkins performs at the opening night gala of the festival -lrb- 5-11 july -rrb- katherine jenkins performs at the opening night gala at llangollen international music eisteddfod .
other artists include violinist nigel kennedy , composer karl jenkins , choir only men aloud and pianist llŷr williams .
nigel kennedy first played at the eisteddfod in 1998 and returns 12 years later with a programme of works by bach and ellington , reflecting his interest in both classical music and jazz .
artists ' weblinks katherine jenkins karl jenkins llŷr williams nigel kennedy only men aloud sinfonia cymru the eisteddfod opens -lrb- 5 july -rrb- with a gala concert starring katherine jenkins , and it 's the following night when welsh composer karl jenkins will be conducting his mass for peace with a ' wales and the world ' choir and an eisteddfod debut for sinfonia cymru .
the programme also includes a performances of beethoven 's 3rd concerto with local musician and world renowned pianist llŷr williams .
other highlights include a visit by four-piece string band bond , whose evening concert - shine - will also include dancers and a 100-strong choir of children .
only men aloud , the winning choir in the bbc 's last choir standing competition , will make their first appearance at the eisteddfod -lrb- 9 july -rrb- and will be singing welsh favourites among other pieces .
and last , but not least , there will be hundreds of performers from 50 nations performing in the pavilion and on the show field during the course of the festival .
llangollen 2010 bookmark with : delicious digg reddit facebook stumbleupon what are these ?

bbc - band reaches finals in anniversary year british broadcasting corporation home accessibility links skip to content skip to local navigation skip to bbc.co.uk navigation skip to bbc.co.uk search help accessibility help nottinghamshire bbc radio nottingham listen live to bbc radio nottingham on iplayer listen again to bbc radio nottingham on iplayer bbc local nottingham things to do people & places nature & outdoors history religion & ethics arts & culture bbc introducing tv & radio local bbc sites news sport weather travel neighbouring sites derby humberside leicester lincolnshire south yorkshire related bbc sites england page last updated at 07:33 gmt , monday , 5 july 2010 08:33 uk band reaches finals in anniversary year please turn on javascript .
media requires javascript to play .
advertisement a band from nottinghamshire has qualified for the final of the national brass band championships in september 2010 .
the championships are held at the royal albert hall , london and attract more than 4,000 music lovers each year to hear the band world 's best ensembles battle for the uk 's top title .
blidworth welfare band hope for success in a year in which they also celebrate their 30th anniversary .

bbc - nottingham faith groups answer james webb 's prayer call british broadcasting corporation home accessibility links skip to content skip to local navigation skip to bbc.co.uk navigation skip to bbc.co.uk search help accessibility help nottinghamshire bbc radio nottingham listen live to bbc radio nottingham on iplayer listen again to bbc radio nottingham on iplayer bbc local nottingham things to do people & places nature & outdoors history religion & ethics arts & culture bbc introducing tv & radio local bbc sites news sport weather travel neighbouring sites derby humberside leicester lincolnshire south yorkshire related bbc sites england page last updated at 07:33 gmt , monday , 5 july 2010 08:33 uk e-mail this to a friend printable version nottingham faith groups answer james webb 's prayer call please turn on javascript .
media requires javascript to play .
nottingham 's faith community have answered an artist 's call to record their prayers .
the prayers of 46 groups , including sunni muslims , orthodox jews , brahma kumaris and humanists have now been turned into an audio installation .
media artist james webb said he wanted to create what it would sound like to listen to all the prayers coming out of the city at one time in one place .
' prayer ' is on at the djanogly art gallery until sunday , 8 august 2010 .
minimalist installation the audio installation is situated in a room accessed through sound-proofed curtains .
the four surrounding walls are bare .
on the floor is a red carpet with 12 black speakers .
it is the only thing in the space .
it is a very visually minimalist installation .
the carpet acts in the same way as a plinth would to present the speakers that are broadcasting the recordings .
james webb explained : " by walking onto the carpet you are walking on to the artistic space .
there is a transformation of space just by that action . "
please turn on javascript .
media requires javascript to play .
the media artist explained that there are two ways of experiencing the work .
" one would be to listen to the entire work as an orchestral piece where you are listening to all the voices at once .
you will do this by wandering through the installation , the floor-based speakers .
" the second way would be to kneel down next to one of the speakers and to listen to that individual voice .
" this would be like wandering through an orchestra and sitting down next to the cello to listen to what the cellist is playing .
" the physical act involved is a reference to supplication or genuflection where the audience have to kneel down and meet that person praying on their knees , " he added .
when you enter the exhibition space it sounds like you are entering a gathering .
at any one time there are six prayers being broadcast at once .
mr webb said that it was up to the audience to decide whether prayer is being questioned or celebrated in the room .
" i believe i have created an image that people will react to depending on their own religious and philosophical beliefs .
i hope people share an intimate moment with these voices james webb , media artist however , he does hope people take the time to listen and " share an intimate moment with these voices . "
higher intelligence the media artist 's project was originally inspired by a story about a group of scientists who sent a pod into space containing information about human civilisation .
the idea was that if a higher intelligence discovered the pod they would be able to find out about the earth .
mr webb said : " this got me thinking as to what it might be like for a higher intelligence to listen to all the prayers that will be coming out of a city or the world at any one time . "
it led to the south african 's first prayer project in his home town of cape town in 2002 .
he now plans to record prayers in cities all over the world .
james webb 's exhibition prayer is on at the djanogly art gallery , lakeside arts centre , nottingham , from saturday , 26 june to sunday , 8 august 2010 .
entry is free .
bookmark with : delicious digg reddit facebook stumbleupon what are these ?

bbc - nottingham - faith groups answer prayer call / religion & ethics bbc local -pipe- nottingham -pipe- things to do -pipe- people & places -pipe- tv & radio -pipe- 07:33 gmt , monday , 5 july 2010 08:33 uk faith groups answer prayer call nottingham 's faith community have answered an artist 's call to record their prayers .

bbc - nottingham - people & places - religion & ethics bbc - nottingham / religion & ethics bbc local -pipe- nottingham -pipe- things to do -pipe- people & places -pipe- tv & radio -pipe- page last updated at 07:39 gmt , monday , 5 july 2010 08:39 uk faith groups answer prayer call nottingham 's faith community have answered an artist 's call to prayer to help create a sound installation .
more religion & ethics nottingham 's thought for the day bbc radio nottingham 's thought for the day offers a daily view from across the local faith spectrum .
notts not jewish enough a family is leaving nottingham because there are n't enough jewish families in the area .
new bishop makes time for tea the new bishop of southwell and nottingham is attempting to visit every vicar in his diocese .
potter heritage centre opens a permanent exhibition opens dedicated to the life of mary potter and the little company of mary .
from bbc news > > asbo church ban for man a man is issued with an asbo banning him from a nottingham church for causing distress to the clergy and congregation , police say .
dj starts bells off for st george bbc radio nottingham presenter sparks a nationwide campaign to mark st george 's day .
nottingham clergy defy act of god a group of nottingham priests spend more than 18 hours being bussed back to the county from spain .
service for polish air-crash dead nottingham 's polish community remember president kaczynski and the 95 others who died when their plane crashed in russia on saturday , 10 april .
christian rockers enter uk chart christian band delirious ? enter the uk chart top ten after an online campaign started by a nottingham church minister .

bbc - north east wales - community events / things to do bbc local -pipe- north east wales -pipe- things to do -pipe- people & places -pipe- tv & radio -pipe- 07:41 gmt , monday , 5 july 2010 08:41 uk community events web links to things to do around north east wales over the coming weeks .
school holidays outdoors music arts & culture festival time july 's a busy month with country shows and festivals including , wrexham science festival -lrb- 1-10 july -rrb- , llangollen international musical eisteddfod -lrb- 6-11 july -rrb- and flint festival -lrb- until 17 july -rrb- .
llangollen eisteddfod 2010 line-up among the region 's country shows , this year 's gwaenynog show -lrb- 9-10 july -rrb- includes vintage vehicles and machinery , tractors , motorcycles , ring events such as dogs and horse shows and more .
gwaenynog show festival round-up return to top arts and culture buckley jubilee as part of celebrations around the annual parade , buckley jubilee , traditionally held on the second tuesday of july , a number of heritage events are being held in buckley library .
jubilee week begins -lrb- july 12 -rrb- with the presentation of the centenary shield at st matthew 's church at 10.30am.
on tuesday -lrb- july 14 -rrb- crowds gather on the common for a religious service at 3pm .
buckley library flintshire local history symposium involves a number of talks by the area 's local history societies at mold library and museum -lrb- 17 july , 10am-1pm -rrb- .
mold library return to top music local colliery bands play on the grimethorpe colliery band perform a fundraising concert in aid of a local charity , the north wales chrysalis trust , based at hm stanley hospital , st asaph at rhyl pavilion -lrb- 17 july -rrb- .
grimethorpe colliery band rhyl pavilion welsh harpist catrin finch performs a concert at the aptly named catrin finch centre , glyndwr university , wrexham , to mark the first anniversary of the building 's opening -lrb- 21 july -rrb- .
catrin finch centre menter iaith sir y fflint and urdd gobaith cymru hold y ffin music festival -lrb- 24 july -rrb- at tower gardens , holywell , featuring welsh bands derwyddon dr gonzo , racehorses , masters in france , yucatan and brigyn .
y ffin return to top nature and outdoors talacre 's new ' keeper ' the first talacre beach festival -lrb- 18 july -rrb- is part of the big dee festival of events and includes kites , competitions , food stalls and more .
clwydian range a live commentary voice trail for , in particular , experienced visually impaired walkers leaves from corwen leisure centre to caer drewyn iron age hillfort .
minibus from loggerheads country park shop .
take a packed lunch -lrb- 22 july -rrb- .
denbighshire council return to top summer holidays our tip : why not tour places where ghosts are said to haunt ?
looking for something to do over the school holidays ?

a pair have nested on the langford lowfields nature reserve , just north of newark on trent .

lourdes of wales why st winefride 's well is known as the lourdes of wales and nuns run the local b & b. bbc local -pipe- north east wales -pipe- things to do -pipe- people & places -pipe- tv & radio -pipe- people & places contents : nature & outdoors -pipe- history -pipe- religion & ethics -pipe- arts & culture -pipe- bbc introducing

bbc - korean war veteran looks back after 60 years british broadcasting corporation home accessibility links skip to content skip to local navigation skip to bbc.co.uk navigation skip to bbc.co.uk search help accessibility help north west wales bbc radio wales listen live to bbc radio wales on iplayer listen again to bbc radio wales on iplayer bbc local north west wales things to do people & places nature & outdoors history religion & ethics arts & culture music tv & radio local bbc sites news sport weather travel neighbouring sites mid wales north east wales related bbc sites wales cymru gogledd orllewin page last updated at 08:13 gmt , monday , 5 july 2010 09:13 uk e-mail this to a friend printable version korean war veteran looks back after 60 years the war ended where it began , with korea split along the 38th parallel warren martin was a schoolboy when the korean war began 60 years ago , but going straight into national service at 18 , he found himself shipped out to join british troops in the conflict .
" i went out right at the end , just before the truce in 1953 , " explained warren from llanfairfechan , who has been back to south korea this year .
" people tend to forget that the last uk troops did n't leave korea until 1957 .
and really , the war still has n't ended , even today , " he said .
the war began on 25 june 1950 when the soviet-backed north korean army invaded the american-backed south .
soon british and commonwealth armed forces were sent over to help fight for the democratic south , and chinese troops were sent in to bolster the communist army to the north .
warren had left friars grammar school , bangor , to start his national service when he found himself facing the formidable chinese army .
" i joined the royal artillery and most of the time i was a wireless officer , operating in front of the guns , " he said .
" it really was a dangerous theatre of war , wherever you were sent .
a peace treaty was never signed : the two koreas remain technically at war " one of the most difficult factors was the climate .
the summers were very hot , like it must be for the boys out in afghanistan now .
" then the winters were very cold , and temperatures could dip to 40 degrees below .
you had to melt the ice for water to wash and shave and starting up the tanks was a problem because sometimes the diesel would freeze .
" we were living in a hole in the ground - something which does n't happen anymore in the army , except for maybe special forces .
but it was back to being in trenches which could get very wet and muddy and in certain sectors compared to world war i. "
warren remembers hemorrhagic fever hitting the troops - a disease with symptoms similar to malaria which cause the skin to split and bleed .
" if it was n't treated within three days , you were dead , " he said .
while the american forces were lectured about their duty to fight for freedom against the communists , warren only remembers the british forces being told to get on with it .
" i was very conscious about what could happen , because i was an only child , and i would n't say i enjoyed it , but i definitely had a taste for it .
over 1000 british troops were killed , 2000 injured and 1000 taken prisoner " i had many friends who tried to be based in raf valley during their national service , so they could go home at weekends , but many have said they regret not taking the opportunity to do something different . "
it definitely gave warren a taste for travel because afterwards he enlisted with the colonial police force and travelled the commonwealth .
earlier this year he was invited to visit korea for the 60th anniversary commemorations .
" it was a very humbling experience , because people of all ages would come up to us , grasp our hands and thank us , " he said .
" it 's known as the forgotten war here , but in south korean schools british soldiers who won the victoria cross for their bravery are held up as heroes .
their vice president said they owed everything to us and our comrades . "
while the five mile-wide no man 's land between north and south reminded him of the continuing hostility , warren was amazed at the changes in seoul which was just piles of rubble last time he was there .
" it 's a beautiful city now , " he said .
" and it was good to be with other veterans who you could talk to openly about the war , sometimes with humour .
it was black humour , but at least it was there . "
bookmark with : delicious digg reddit facebook stumbleupon what are these ?

bbc - north west wales - korean war veteran looks back / history bbc local -pipe- north west wales -pipe- things to do -pipe- people & places -pipe- tv & radio -pipe- 08:13 gmt , monday , 5 july 2010 09:13 uk korean war veteran looks back warren martin was a schoolboy when the korean war began 60 years ago , but going straight into national service at 18 , he found himself shipped out to join british troops in the conflict .

" one of the most difficult factors was the climate .

" then the winters were very cold , and temperatures could dip to 40 degrees below .

their vice president said they owed everything to us and our comrades . "

" it 's a beautiful city now , " he said .
" and it was good to be with other veterans who you could talk to openly about the war , sometimes with humour .
it was black humour , but at least it was there . "

senator wants competitive sports senator james perchard wants to see more competitive sports in the islands primary and secondary schools .
communicating with orangutans orangutans at the durrell wildlife trust in jersey were studied by animal behaviour experts for an ape dictionary .
more people & places tourism concern over met maps jersey tourism fears the island could be losing visitors because it does n't feature on uk weather forecasts .
danny young named mr battle 2010 the former coronation street and dancing on ice star , danny young , will be mr jersey battle of flowers 2010 .
string of luck saves ' bionic ' cat oscar is a cat from jersey and has found fame after receiving bionic paws in a pioneering operation in england .
hospice sets cycle challenge jersey cycle challenge raises money for hospice and in memory of a keen fundraiser for the island charity .
single election day for jersey for the first time jersey will have a general election day with all but six members elected at the same time .
states need to plan energy future jersey electricity 's commercial director has called on the states or get on with debating the islands energy policy .
new red ensign for jersey boats the states of jersey has agreed on a new red ensign that locally-registered ships can fly to identify them as jersey .
honey used in jersey seasonal ale honey from a mile away from the brewery is to be used in a new seasonal ale produced by the liberation group .
driftwood used as waterfront seat a piece of driftwood that was placed on the waterfront has already become a regularly used meeting place .
award for heathland sheep farmer a shepherd whose rare flock of horned sheep graze on jersey 's heathland has won an environmental award .

new chapter for ' oldest brand ' as east london 's tate & lyle announces it is selling off its sugar division bbc london takes a look at how it has adapted over its 127 years of business .
more people & places cathedral centenary celebrated as westminster cathedral marks the 100th anniversary since it was consecrated a special exhibition is to be launched to exhibit its treasures .
webcams : views of london take a look at a selection of webcams around london including the london 2012 olympic park and the iconic trafalgar square .

you can help by choosing them .

bbc - sheffield & south yorkshire - people & places - arts & culture bbc - sheffield & south yorkshire / arts & culture bbc local -pipe- south yorkshire -pipe- things to do -pipe- people & places -pipe- tv & radio -pipe- page last updated at 08:39 gmt , monday , 5 july 2010 09:39 uk what sheffield means to me in june 2010 bbc sheffield took a look at what culture means in the city of sheffield , ahead of the uk city of culture announcement .
creating a symphony for yorkshire yorkshire musicians have been recording a symphony commissioned by the bbc to reflect the region in words and music .
we speak to composer benjamin till .
more arts & culture restored paintings back on show paintings of sheffield which were damaged in the floods of june 2007 have been painstakingly restored and will be back on show .
cross your fingers sheffield paulette edwards looks back on her ' big up sheffield ' pitch and crosses her fingers for the announcement expected in july .
ken loach supports sheffield film the british federation of film societies has announced that the english film director , ken loach , has become the first patron of the sheffield organisation .
echoes of blackburn meadows young volunteers are needed for conservation work on the site of the old tinsley towers and blackburn meadows power station .
industrial sheffield 's last scissor factory in the 1970s sheffield boasted no less than 150 small scissor companies .
now there are just two .
one of those companies is kutrite , established in 1902 as ernest wright & son .
from suffolk > > 125-year-old brass band ron wright started his brass band career with markham main colliery band when he was 12 .
now he plays for a 125-year-old suffolk band .
saving portland works portland works was sheffield 's first purpose-built cutlery works .
now the tenants are campaigning to stop it from being turned into flats .
sheffield films ' roaring success sheffield 's latest film had a fantastic launch week , despite its controversial subject matter - terrorism .
a personal collection : of shoes barnsley civic is hosting a private collection of shoes .
these are n't just any old shoes but are created by the world renowned designer vivienne westwood .
wham !
bam !
steel finger comic man !
jim connolly has drawn ufos zapping the tinsley towers and zombies taking over meadowhall .
the latest poster is steel finger .

bbc - sheffield & south yorkshire - things to do bbc - sheffield & south yorkshire / things to do bbc local -pipe- south yorkshire -pipe- things to do -pipe- people & places -pipe- tv & radio -pipe- page last updated at 08:39 gmt , monday , 5 july 2010 09:39 uk creating a symphony for yorkshire yorkshire musicians have been recording a symphony commissioned by the bbc to reflect the region in words and music .
we speak to composer benjamin till .
take the five weirs walk find out more about the eight kilometre walk along the city 's five weirs - starting in sheffield and ending at meadowhall .
more things to do p.t barnum exhibition hits sheffield humbug ! is an exhibition at sheffield university celebrating 200 years of public entertainment by the showman p.t. barnum .
raw talent at the o2 academy get your tickets for bbc radio sheffield 's fourth raw talent live at the o2 academy in sheffield .
women on wheels in sheffield roller derby is an aggressive , full contact , competitive sport for women on wheels and it is taking off in the city of sheffield .
a history of women in industry a look back at the impact that women of south yorkshire have had on industrial heritage .
warp 's return to sheffield independent record and film label warp started in sheffield in 1989 .
20 years later they returned .
a personal collection : of shoes barnsley civic is hosting a private collection of shoes created by the world famous designer vivienne westwood .
brian blessed is mr bojagi all the best ideas happen in pubs , whether it 's a blast of inspiration of what to buy a loved one for their birthday or business collaboration .
imagine if both happened at once .
tenants and residents make a difference we speak to one of the people who make sure our grass-roots issues are voiced .
pictures of sheffield : the exhibition visit the pictures of sheffield old and new photography exhibition in castle market .
echoes of blackburn meadows young volunteers are needed for conservation work on the site of the old tinsley towers .
tell your history of the world bbc radio sheffield wants to feature some of your history of the world items .
get in touch !
flight of the ultimate frisbee at endcliffe park in sheffield you can see something that little bit different ...
a frisbee game called ultimate .

bbc - sheffield & south yorkshire - people & places - bbc introducing bbc - sheffield & south yorkshire / bbc introducing bbc local -pipe- south yorkshire -pipe- things to do -pipe- people & places -pipe- tv & radio -pipe- page last updated at 08:39 gmt , monday , 5 july 2010 09:39 uk creating a symphony for yorkshire yorkshire musicians have been recording a symphony commissioned by the bbc to reflect the region in words and music .
we speak to composer benjamin till .
presenter profile : iain hodgson iain hodgson is the presenter for bbc radio sheffield 's raw talent .
you can hear him on thursday from 7-10pm .

more music upload your music to raw talent find out how to get your unsigned music on to the raw talent programme on bbc radio sheffield .
from bbc news > > hawley joined by monkey on stage richard hawley teams up with arctic monkeys frontman alex turner at a london gig that saw him hint at a future collaboration .
warp 's return to sheffield the independent record and film label warp returned to their home town for their 20th birthday .
from suffolk > > 125-year-old brass band ron wright started his brass band career with markham main colliery band when he was 12 .
now he plays for a 125-year-old suffolk band .
raw talent at the o2 academy it 's the fourth raw talent live gig at sheffield 's o2 academy on saturday .
check out the line up and get your tickets .
the beatles at the gaumont in 1965 a sheffield nightclub played host to the beatles at the height of their fame , but during the gig there was an incident involving a pear drop and paul mccartney !
memories of sheffield fiesta bob mundy was roy orbison 's drummer for six years from 1967 to 1974 before becoming a compère at the fiesta nightclub in sheffield .

bbc news - timeline : guinea british broadcasting corporation home accessibility links mobile version skip to content skip to local navigation skip to bbc.co.uk navigation skip to bbc.co.uk search help accessibility help bbc news updated every minute of every day one-minute world news news front page africa americas asia-pacific europe middle east south asia uk business health science & environment technology entertainment also in the news - video and audio - programmes have your say in pictures country profiles special reports related bbc sites sport weather on this day editors ' blog bbc world service languages somali french arabic swahili great lakes hausa portuguese africa more page last updated at 08:41 gmt , monday , 5 july 2010 09:41 uk e-mail this to a friend printable version timeline : guinea a chronology of key events 1891 - france declares guinea to be a colony , separate from senegal .
ahmed sekou toure led guinea at independence .
thousands died or disappeared during his 26-year rule guinea 's 50 years of poverty 1898 - defeat of resistance to french occupation led by samory toure , great-grandfather of future president ahmed sekou toure .
1906 - guinea becomes part of french west african federation .
1952 - ahmed sekou toure becomes secretary-general of the democratic party of guinea .
independence 1958 october - guinea becomes independent , with ahmed sekou toure as president .
1965 - sekou toure breaks off relations with france after accusing it of plotting to oust him .
1984 march - sekou toure dies .
1984 april - lansana conte and diarra traore seize power in bloodless coup .
conte becomes president while traore is installed as prime minister .
1985 - attempted coup organized by traore following his demotion to education minister .
1990 - constitution paving the way for civilian government is adopted .
democracy without peace 1993 - first multiparty elections are held ; conte confirmed in office .
guinea sheltered many refugees who fled liberia 's civil war 1995 - conte 's party of unity and progress wins 71 of the national assembly 's 114 seats .
1996 - some 30 people are killed and presidential palace set on fire as 25 % of guinea 's armed forces mutiny over low pay , poor conditions .
2000 september - alpha conde , leader of opposition guinean people 's rally , sentenced to five years in prison for endangering state security and recruiting foreign mercenaries .
he is pardoned in may 2001 .
2000 september - start of incursions by rebels in guinea 's border regions with liberia and sierra leone which eventually claim more than 1,000 lives and cause massive population displacement .
the government accuses liberia , the sierra leonean united revolutionary front -lrb- ruf -rrb- rebel group , burkina faso and former guinean army mutineers of trying to destabilise guinea .
2001 february - government deploys attack helicopters to the front-line in its fight with rebels .
referendum 2001 november - official results show constitutional referendum , boycotted by opposition , endorses president conte 's proposal to extend presidential term from five to seven years .
critics accuse mr conte of trying to stay in power for life .
2002 march - guinea , sierra leone , liberia agree on measures to secure mutual borders and to tackle insurgency .
2003 november - opposition leader jean-marie dore detained , subsequently released , after saying president conte is too ill to contest december 's presidential election .
2003 december - president conte wins a third term in elections boycotted by the opposition .
2004 april - prime minister lounseny fall resigns while visiting the us .
2005 january - president conte survives what security officials say is an assassination attempt .
shots were fired as his motorcade passed through the capital .
2005 july - alpha conde , head of the main opposition guinean people 's rally , returns from exile in france .
he is welcomed by thousands of supporters .
2006 march - president conte is flown to switzerland for medical treatment .
opposition parties call for the formation of an interim government .
2006 april - prime minister cellou dalein diallo sacked .
strikes and protests protesters blamed president conte for poor living standards q & a : guinea emergency 2007 : guinea 's strongman feels the heat 2006 june - crippling general strike suspended after eight days after trade unions , government agree on wages and prices of basic goods .
several student protesters were killed during unrest over the postponement of exams due to the strike .
2006 october - president conte fails to make his usual independence day speech , fuelling concerns about his health .
2007 january - general strike called by unions , opposition in protest against the rule of president conte .
several people are killed in clashes between demonstrators and police .
2007 13 february - president conte declares a state of emergency , instructs the army to restore order following days of violent protests .
lansana conte seized power in 1984 and ruled until he died in 2008 leader who unified , repressed 2007 26 february - president names lansana kouyate as prime minister under a deal to end the general strike .
2007 may - violent protests as soldiers demand better pay .
2007 august - government announces discovery of commercially viable reserves of uranium .
2008 may - president sacks lansana kouyate as prime minister and replaces him with former minister of mines and ally ahmed tidiane souare .
soldiers begin a mutiny over pay .
conte dies , military seizes power 2008 december - military seizes power within hours of death of president lansana conte .
the coup meets with international condemnation , but many guineans back the army 's move .
stadium massacre more than 150 killed after military opened fire on opposition gathering human rights watch alleges army encircled stadium and stormed in to shoot and rape international criminal court says killing was a crime against humanity action on 28 september 2009 widely condemned captain moussa dadis camara emerges as leader of the new military junta and declares himself president .
junta appoints former banker kabine komara as prime minister .
2009 august - military leader captain moussa dadis camara says presidential elections will be held on 31 january 2010 and elections for parliament in march .
despite a previous promise that he would not seek election , his supporters form a movement urging him to stand .
2009 september - soldiers open fire on a mass opposition rally at a stadium in conakry , called to urge military ruler moussa camara to step down .
the guinean human rights organisation says 157 are killed in the violence and over 1200 injured .
the military government puts the death toll at 57 , and bans all " subversive " gatherings .
2009 october - the european union , the african union and the us united states impose sanctions .
the united nations sets up a tribunal to probe the death of at least 150 protesters , who died when troops fired on an anti-government demonstration in september .
2009 december - captain camara is shot in the head by a former aide .
2010 january - after receiving treatment in morocco , captain camara goes to burkina faso to recuperate .
capt camara agrees to stay abroad and leave his deputy gen sekouba konate in charge .
pro-democracy opposition leader and civilian jean-marie dore is appointed interim pm to head a power-sharing government and oversee a return to civilian rule .
2010 february - international criminal court -lrb- icc -rrb- says september stadium massacre was a crime against humanity .
2010 may - campaigning kicks off for 27 june presidential election .
military junta promises to respect result .
2010 june - presidential elections .
first round produces no outright winner .
ex-prime minister cellou dalein diallo faces veteran opposition figure alpha conde in a run-off on 18 july .

bbc - jedward and pixie lott in weston for t4 on the beach british broadcasting corporation home accessibility links skip to content skip to local navigation skip to bbc.co.uk navigation skip to bbc.co.uk search help accessibility help bristol bbc radio bristol listen live to bbc radio bristol on iplayer listen again to bbc radio bristol on iplayer bbc local bristol things to do people & places nature & outdoors history religion & ethics arts & culture bbc introducing tv & radio local bbc sites news sport weather travel neighbouring sites gloucestershire somerset south east wales wiltshire related bbc sites england page last updated at 08:51 gmt , monday , 5 july 2010 09:51 uk e-mail this to a friend jedward and pixie lott in weston for t4 on the beach thousands packed the beach at weston-super-mare on sunday for the annual t4 on the beach event - which saw bands such as jls performing .
rapper dizzee rascal was one of the headline acts - his set went down well with the crowd despite the bad weather which saw rain fall for much of the day in north somerset .
those lucky enough to get to the front huddled underneath anything they could find to keep dry .
one casualty of the day was edward grimes from jedward who injured himself during a performance of ghostbusters .
other acts gracing the stage included pixie lott known for chart-topping songs such as mama do -lrb- uh oh , uh oh -rrb- and boys and girls .
hip-hop group n-dubz , on the back of their latest album against all odds , also braved the conditions in weston .
brit award-winner kelis was another of the acts to perform at the event which has been in weston-super-mare for the past six years .
x-factor semi-finalist diana vickers , whose album songs from the tainted cherry tree topped the charts in may , also took to the beach-front stage .

bbc - in pictures : different ways to cross the river thames british broadcasting corporation home accessibility links skip to content skip to local navigation skip to bbc.co.uk navigation skip to bbc.co.uk search help accessibility help london bbc london 94.9 listen live to bbc london 94.9 on iplayer listen again to bbc london 94.9 on iplayer bbc local london things to do people & places nature & outdoors history religion & ethics arts & culture bbc introducing 2012 tv & radio local bbc sites news sport weather travel neighbouring sites beds herts bucks berkshire essex kent surrey related bbc sites england page last updated at 08:52 gmt , monday , 5 july 2010 09:52 uk e-mail this to a friend in pictures : different ways to cross the river thames in 1825 work began to build the first ever tunnel under the thames linking rotherhithe and wapping .
designed by sir marc brunel and assisted by his son isambard the pedestrian tunnel took 18 years to complete and finally opened in 1843 .
a model of old london bridge , circa 1440 .
throughout its history the bridge has been a busy thoroughfare .
it was once lined with shops and houses .
london bridge is the earliest known in london and can be dated to the roman times .
the albert bridge between chelsea and battersea in london , circa 1885 .
it opened in 1872 and is a grade ii * listed road bridge .
a tunnel bus emerges from blackwall tunnel in 1912 .
the original tunnel opened in 1897 and links east greenwich and east india dock road in poplar .
the woolwich ferry , 1932 .
ferry crossings at woolwich can be traced to the 13th century .
woolwich was a fishing village and had a right to run a ferry across the thames .
the free woolwich ferry in operation today was established in the late 1880s .
greenwich foot tunnel opened in 1902 so that south london residents could go to work in the docks on the isle of dogs .
the tunnel is 1,217 feet long and runs about 50 feet under the river thames .
there is another foot tunnel at woolwich .
in 2003 the american illusionist david blaine spent 44 days suspended in a glass box over the river thames in london without food .
the london millennium footbridge opened in 2000 and links the city of london with south london by the tate modern .
the latest footbridge opened in 2002 - the golden jubilee bridges , sometimes known as hungerford bridge .
tower bridge is the last bridge between london and dartford , kent .
the bridge opened in 1894 .
prior to the bridge there was the tower subway , a tunnel dug in 1869 allowing people to cross under the thames .
it was the first tube tunnel rather than brick .
there are 20 tunnels under the river thames including tube and dlr routes .
there are ferries , foot tunnels and over 20 bridges in london .
the proposed cable car for london 2012 would be the first of its kind .
see also thames cable car for 2012 games 04 jul 10 -pipe- london other related bbc links 360 views : london 's bridges e-mail this to a friend bookmark with : delicious digg reddit facebook stumbleupon what are these ?

bbc - dorset - people & places - history british broadcasting corporation home accessibility links bbc mobile mobiles skip to content skip to local navigation skip to bbc.co.uk navigation skip to bbc.co.uk search help accessibility help access keys help dorset bbc radio solent listen live to bbc radio solent on iplayer listen again to bbc radio solent on iplayer bbc local dorset things to do people & places nature & outdoors history religion & ethics arts & culture bbc introducing tv & radio local bbc sites news sport weather travel neighbouring sites devon guernsey hampshire somerset related bbc sites england history local feeds page last updated at 08:56 gmt , monday , 5 july 2010 09:56 uk jurassic coast is evolution story a former teacher who is now a writer is hoping to tell the story of the geology of the jurassic coast in a simplified way .
local flag revived after 85 years a flag known to have been flown by dorset men fighting at the battle of agincourt in 1415 , has been revived by the society of dorset men .
poole quay 's dunkirk little ship the old lifeboat station on poole quay is home to a registered dunkirk little ship , the thomas kirk wright , which helped to bring british and allied troops back to england in 1940 .

bbc - dorset - people & places - history bbc - dorset / history bbc local -pipe- dorset -pipe- things to do -pipe- people & places -pipe- tv & radio -pipe- page last updated at 08:56 gmt , monday , 5 july 2010 09:56 uk jurassic coast is evolution story a former teacher who is now a writer is hoping to tell the story of the geology of the jurassic coast in a simplified way .
local flag revived after 85 years a flag known to have been flown by dorset men fighting at the battle of agincourt in 1415 , has been revived by the society of dorset men .
poole quay 's dunkirk little ship the old lifeboat station on poole quay is home to a registered dunkirk little ship , the thomas kirk wright , which helped to bring british and allied troops back to england in 1940 .
more history from bbc news > > veteran recalls life as a pow a wwii veteran recalls for the first time how he was captured as a prisoner of war as his fellow comrades were rescued at dunkirk .
ageing water main to be replaced a 300m water main which has supplied homes in weymouth for more than 70 years is being replaced .
plague tale for preston novelist a woman from preston has published a novel set against the devastating spread of the black death plague , which arrived in england at weymouth .
poet barnes ' deserves acclaim ' a professor studying the work of dorset writer and poet william barnes believes the poet 's work deserves a wider audience .
book charts bournemouth 's hotels as bournemouth marks its 200th year , a woman who runs a b & b in the town has looked back on a ' key part ' of bournemouth life - its hotels .
1937 phone box reconnected a man from portland is reconnecting a 1937 red phone box to the exchange , so he can make calls on it using pre-decimal coinage .
victorian taxidermy auctioned a collection of victorian taxidermy from a closed museum on the isle of wight has been auctioned in dorchester , reaching a total of £ 280,000 .
weymouth history shots restored a deteriorating stash of negatives showing weymouth in the 1950s has been saved by dorset history centre - the life 's work of a dorset photographer .
hardy 's manuscripts the manuscripts of famous author thomas hardy are coming ' home ' to dorset , thanks to the dorset county museum , in dorchester .
garden centres ' began in dorset ' new documents at the dorset history centre show the growth of a dorset garden centre , and it may have been the first in britain .

bbc - in pictures : cleveleys new £ 19m modern seafront opens british broadcasting corporation home accessibility links skip to content skip to local navigation skip to bbc.co.uk navigation skip to bbc.co.uk search help accessibility help lancashire bbc radio lancashire listen live to bbc radio lancashire on iplayer listen again to bbc radio lancashire on iplayer bbc local lancashire things to do people & places tv & radio local bbc sites news sport weather travel neighbouring sites bradford cumbria isle of man liverpool manchester north yorkshire related bbc sites england page last updated at 08:56 gmt , monday , 5 july 2010 09:56 uk e-mail this to a friend printable version in pictures : cleveleys new £ 19m modern seafront opens cleveleys newly-built seafront has officially opened after undergoing a £ 19m redevelopment five years of work has transformed the promenade , which now features additional shelters , furniture and artwork with modern lighting a new seawall also provides much improved protection from tidal flooding to the residents of cleveleys art work will appear throughout the next 18 months and wyre borough council will continue to work with the cleveleys seafront partnership to make full use of the new public open space areas , holding events and activities a day of entertainment including a grand parade along the promenade marked the opening of the new seafront elsewhere on the web wyre borough council cleveleys seafront partnership e-mail this to a friend printable version bookmark with : delicious digg reddit facebook stumbleupon what are these ?

bbc - lancashire - things to do bbc - lancashire / things to do bbc local -pipe- lancashire -pipe- things to do -pipe- people & places -pipe- tv & radio -pipe- page last updated at 08:57 gmt , monday , 5 july 2010 09:57 uk things to do in lancashire a few suggestions to help you plan the next few weeks including music , arts and the great outdoors !
pedal car power comes to darwen the green light has been given for a new grand prix race around darwen town centre this july - in pedal cars !
more things to do blackpool youth games kick off lancashire school children are warming up for an action-packed week of activity as the blackpool youth games get underway .
lancashire tourism goes ape there 's a swinging time to be had in rivington at go ape .
it has been named the best tourism experience of the year of 2010 .
presenters ' great days out with the lancashire and blackpool tourism awards out , the county 's best loved presenters tell us their best loved lancashire hot spots .

in pictures : cleveleys new seafront cleveleys newly-built seafront has officially opened after undergoing a £ 19m redevelopment taking five years .
pedal car power comes to darwen the green light has been given for a new grand prix race around darwen town centre this july - in pedal cars !

a historic look at why we dial 999 for the emergency services and how the calls came into place over 70 years ago .
